Reference flow: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of Acai berry at the farm, with standard water content (89.0%). The reference flow is the average yield per hectare and year: 7.5 t/ha, obtained under irrigated conditions (total  amount of water 1862 m3/ha). Allocation: No allocationSystem boundaries: Cradle-to-gate. The inventory includes the processes of tree seedling production and planting, fertilisation (mineral and manure), irrigation and harvest.  Equipment infrastructure is also considered, such as for sprinkler irrigation. Direct field emissions from crop production activities (e.g. fertiliser) and land use change (LUC) are considered. Irrigation is based on blue water from Pfister for tropical fruits in Brazil. LUC for "Fruit, tropical fresh nes" is considered. 100% surface water powered with diesel is considered. No pesticides are applied for acai cultivation according to Bichara 2011. Fertilizers and manure application are assumed to be 100% manual (very low mechanization level). The harvest is assumed to be manual harvesting, the harvest baskets are not included. The harvested fruits are quickly transported to a transformation place where the pulp is extracted and then sold or frozen or further processed. These post-harvest steps are excluded. Translated name: Almonds, at farm (WFLDB 3.7)Included processes: The inventory includes all activities of a year in the productive phase of the orchard, i.e. fertiliser and pesticide application, mowing, harvesting, irrigation and prune in winter. Machine infrastructure including a shed for shelter and fuel use are also considered as well as transport on the farm. Direct field emissions from crop production activities and from land use change are considered. The establishment phase of the orchard, i.e. tree nursery, soil cultivation, planting trees, sowing grass, installation of irrigation. Fertiliser and pesticide use in a year of the establishment phase is assumed to be half of the amount of a year in the productive phase. No processing included (hulling and shelling). Remark: The functional unit is the production of 1 kg of almonds. The reference flow is the average yield per ha and year for the reference period of 2009 - 2012: yield (2.9 t/ha) obtained under irrigated conditions (total amount of water 2133 m3/ha). column1: DataThe ecoinvent v3 database contains LCI data from various sectors such as energy production, transport, building materials, production of chemicals, metal production and fruit and vegetables. The entire database consists of over 10,000 interlinked datasets, each of which describes a life cycle inventory on a process level. The complete list of dataset names, elementary flow names and regional codes and conversion from ecoinvent v2 to v3 can be found in the Excel correspondence file which can be found in the SimaPro Help menu. Also other Ecoinvent documents can be found in the Help menu.Market and transformation activitiesActivity types are introduced in the ecoinvent v3 database. The most important activity types include transforming activities and market activities. Transforming activities are human activities that transform inputs so that the output of the activity is different from the inputs, e.g. a hard coal mine that transforms hard coal in ground to the marketable product hard coal. Market activities transfers this output to the transforming activities that consumes it as an input e.g. from hard coal at the supplier to hard coal at the consumer.  The output of a market activity is a consumption mix. Consumption mixes represent production-volume-weighted averages of the suppliers to a specific market. A treatment activity is a transforming activity with a reference product with a negative sign meaning that the activity is supplying the service of treating or disposing of the reference product. In SimaPro, treatment activities which are supplying the service of disposing of the reference product are linked to Waste treatment datasets which are especially created to be able to use waste scenarios. Global datasetsEcoinvent 2 had many regional datasets and it was a wish of many users to have international data in the database. In ecoinvent v3, all activities have a global dataset covering the average global production. It has to be realised that, currently, many of the global datasets are extrapolated from one of the existing regional datasets due to lack of global data. These datasets are described as extrapolated in the Documentation tab under Data treatment. The increased uncertainty from these extrapolations is quantified by the pedigree matrix which can be found in the process sheet.Direct comparison The data in the ecoinvent database are not primarily suited for direct comparisons due to averaging. For example waste management datasets shall not be used for directly assessing waste management policies (such as land filling versus incineration) and farming systems (such as integrated, extensive or organic farming) shall not directly and solely be compared based on ecoinvent data. In these cases the systems for comparison have to be thoroughly defined beforehand and it has to be checked which adaptations to the average ecoinvent data would be necessary to appropriately describe these systems according to the goals of the study. +++Database versionsThe ecoinvent v3 database is originally composed of unlinked, multi-product datasets. Different versions of the processes can be obtained by applying a system model, providing the rules for linking the datasets into contiguous product systems. To make the database compatible with SimaPro, only linked datasets are implemented, to which a system model has already been applied. Different versions of the database are included in SimaPro to allow the user to switch between three system models: "allocation, recycled content", ''allocation, default' (attributional database) and 'consequential'. The system model allocation, recycled content uses the same attributional and cut-off approach as is used in the ecoinvent v2 database. The cut-off approach means that primary production of materials is always allocated to the primary user of a material. If a material is recycled, the primary producer does not receive any credit for the provision of any recyclable materials. The consequence is that recyclable materials are available burden-free to recycling processes and secondary (recycled) materials bear only the impacts of the recycling processes. Also, producers of wastes do not receive any credit for the recycling or re-use of products resulting out of any waste treatment.The system model allocation, default uses the same attributional approach as the ecoinvent v2 database. The attributional system model contains two methodological choices: 1) it uses the average supply of products, as described in market activity datasets and 2) it uses partitioning (allocation) to convert multi-product datasets to single-product datasets. The flows are allocated relative to their 'true value', which is the economic revenue corrected for some market imperfections and fluctuations. The consequential system model handles these two methodological choices differently: 1) it uses the unconstrained supply of products, based on market activity datasets as well as the included information on technology level and 2) it uses substitution (system expansion) to convert multi-product datasets to single-product datasets. The possibility of using consequential allocation gives practitioners an alternative to the default attributional approach. The two attributional  databases and the consequential database are available in SimaPro using unit and system processes. Unit processes contain links to other unit processes, from which the inventory flows can be calculated by SimaPro. System processes contain the already calculated inventory flows and do not contain links to other processes. If you use processes from the ecoinvent database as background processes, it is recommended to use system processes to increase calculation speed. Unit processes can be used for detailed interpretation and uncertainty analysis using Monte Carlo. Due to their looped structure, analysis of unit processes may take some time, depending on the speed of your computer. Both unit and system processes give the same result, although occasionally there is a minor difference due to rounding errors. Please note that it is possible to switch between unit and system libraries when defining a calculation setup. +++Category structureAll processes are assigned to a particular category and one or more subcategories within SimaPro. Please note that PR� Consultants uses a different (sub-)category structure than ecoinvent to make the data compatible with the SimaPro database structure and the category names already used in SimaPro.+++ProcessesThe functional unit of all processes is either a product or a service, where a product may be as large as a complete power plant manufactured for producing electricity. Process datasheets are identified unequivocally by their name, which includes the name of the process, the geographical location, the type of activity, the system model and a suffix,  S for system processes or U for unit processes. +++More informationFor detailed information, please see the information supplied on the ecoinvent website, www.ecoinvent.org, which includes  ecoinvent reports, spreadsheets of all data and a series of additional tools. The ecoinvent reports can also be accessed through SimaPro, via the Help menu.It is recommended to read the, Data quality guideline for the ecoinvent database version 3 and the Documentation of changes implemented in ecoinvent database v 3.1, also available on the ecoinvent website, which contains detailed information on the ecoinvent database. +++SUPPORTThe ecoinvent Centre put special emphasis on the very detailed documentation of the ecoinvent data in the ecoinvent reports and in the meta information included in each dataset. If - even after reading these documents - questions remain, the first contact point is the author responsible for the specific dataset, whose name and email address are provided in the meta information of each dataset. +++TERMS OF USEThe ecoinvent terms of use (v1.1) state that "the licensee is not entitled to use the ecoinvent database or the ecoinvent datasets by preparing extracts or for any further commercial purposes. The licensee is not entitled to reproduce, disseminate or publicly display any significant portions of the ecoinvent database or the ecoinvent datasets."This means that raw ecoinvent LCI data and results and LCIA results (whether directly taken from the ecoinvent database or calculated with ecoinvent LCI results and factors taken from the ecoinvent database) shall not be reproduced in LCA studies that do not fall under the license. When showing results using e.g. contribution analysis this may include graphical representation of the share of ecoinvent processes on the total LCA results, e.g. the contribution of energy supply to the total burdens of manufacturing a mobile phone. However, hereby the possibilities to recalculate the exact LCI and LCIA results of an ecoinvent dataset shall be prevented as much as possible.The full terms of use can be found on the ecoinvent website, www.ecoinvent.org. If you have any questions, please contact the ecoinvent helpdesk. Note that apart from the ecoinvent term of use, the normal SimaPro license conditions apply.+++SourcesWeidema, B. et al (2012), Overview and methodology.
